trans-unit.source: Encapsulates all HTTP-specific information about an individual HTTP request.
Classes that inherit the <xref:System.Web.IHttpModule> and <xref:System.Web.IHttpHandler> interfaces are provided a reference to an <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> object for the current HTTP request.

The object provides access to the intrinsic <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Request%2A>, <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Response%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Server%2A> properties for the request.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref> class that uses the specified worker-request object.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpWorkerRequest"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref> class by using the specified request and response objects.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpResponse"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
Accepts an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request using the specified user function.
Calling this method is equivalent to calling the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.AcceptWebSocketRequest%2A> method overload and passing `null` for the `options` parameter.
The user function.
The userFunc parameter is `null`.
The request is not an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request.
Accepts an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request using the specified user function and options object.
The user function.
The options object.
The userFunc parameter is `null`.
The request is not an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request.
Adds an exception to the exception collection for the current HTTP request.
The <xref href="System.Exception"></xref> to add to the exception collection.
Raises a virtual event that occurs when the HTTP part of the request is ending.
This event occurs before the <xref:System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket> connection begins.
The HTTP context object.
The subscription token.
The callback parameter is `null`.
Gets an array of errors accumulated while processing an HTTP request.
An array of <xref href="System.Exception"></xref> objects for the current HTTP request.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether asynchronous operations are allowed during parts of ASP.NET request processing when they are not expected.
If this flag is not set to `true`, ASP.NET will throw an exception when it detects the application misusing the async API.

This can occur if you try to call an asynchronous method during a part of the request processing pipeline where asynchronous operations are not expected, or if there is still outstanding asynchronous work when an asynchronous module or handler signals completion.
This behavior is meant as a safety net to let you know early on if you're writing async code that doesn't fit expected patterns and might have negative side effects.
`false` if ASP.NET will throw an exception when the asynchronous API is used at a time when it is not expected; otherwise, `true`.
The default value is `false`.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplicationState"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplicationState"></xref> for the current HTTP request.
To get the <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> object for the current HTTP request, use <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext.ApplicationInstance"></xref>.

(ASP.NET uses `ApplicationInstance` instead of `Application` as a property name to refer to the current <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> instance in order to avoid confusion between ASP.NET and classic ASP.
In classic ASP, `Application` refers to the global application state dictionary.)
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> for the current HTTP request.

ASP.NET uses `ApplicationInstance` instead of `Application` as a property name to refer to the current <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> instance in order to avoid confusion between ASP.NET and classic ASP.
In classic ASP, `Application` refers to the global application state dictionary.
The Web application is running under IIS 7.0 in Integrated mode, and an attempt was made to change the property value from a non-null value to `null`.
Gets or sets an object that contains flags that pertain to asynchronous preload mode.

The first time this property is accessed, the object that contains flags for asynchronous preload mode is loaded from the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.HttpRuntimeSection.AsyncPreloadMode%2A> setting in the configuration file.
Although this property can be set programmatically, changing the property value only has effect if the property is set before the `ExecuteRequestHandler` step in the ASP.NET request pipeline.
An object that contains flags that pertain to asynchronous preload mode.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.Caching.Cache"></xref> object for the current application domain.
There is one instance of the <xref:System.Web.Caching.Cache> class per application domain.

As a result, the <xref:System.Web.Caching.Cache> object that is returned by the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Cache%2A> property is the <xref:System.Web.Caching.Cache> object for all requests in the application domain.
The <xref href="System.Web.Caching.Cache"></xref> for the current application domain.
Clears all errors for the current HTTP request.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
This property is a static property of the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> class.
The property stores the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> instance that applies to the current request.
The properties of this instance are the non-static properties of the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> class.
You can also use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.Context%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property to access the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> object for the current HTTP request.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref> instance for the current HTTP request.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> object that represents the currently executing handler.

The currently executing handler that is referenced by the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.CurrentHandler%2A> property might be different than the handler that is referenced by the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Handler%2A> property.
This can occur when another handler was requested by using the <xref:System.Web.HttpServerUtility.Execute%2A> method or the <xref:System.Web.HttpServerUtility.Transfer%2A> method.
When the currently executing handler finishes processing, the previously determined handler is restored.
An <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> that represents the currently executing handler.
Gets a <xref href="System.Web.RequestNotification"></xref> value that indicates the current <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> event that is processing.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.CurrentNotification%2A> property requires the integrated pipeline mode in [!INCLUDE[iisver](~/includes/iisver-md.md)] and at least the .NET Framework version 3.0.
When available, the property returns a <xref:System.Web.RequestNotification> value.
The value of the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.CurrentNotification%2A> property indicates which event in the <xref:System.Web.HttpApplication> instance is currently processing the request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.CurrentNotification%2A> property is not intended to be set.
Instead, it is set by [!INCLUDE[iisver](~/includes/iisver-md.md)] during the processing of the request in the ASP.NET pipeline.
Setting the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.CurrentNotification%2A> property will result in a compilation error.
<xref:System.Web.HttpContext.CurrentNotification%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/docs/framework/migration-guide/versions-and-dependencies.md).
One of the <xref href="System.Web.RequestNotification"></xref> values.
The operation requires integrated pipeline mode in [!INCLUDE[iisver](~/includes/iisver-md.md)] and at least the .NET Framework version 3.0.

Enables an object's <xref href="System.IDisposable.Dispose"></xref> method to be called when the <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> connection part of this request is completed.
The <xref:System.IDisposable.Dispose%2A> method of the target object is called after both the HTTP part of the request and the <xref:System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket> connection have ended.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> object is not available for inspection.
The object whose <xref href="System.IDisposable.Dispose"></xref> method must be called when the <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> connection part of the request is completed.
The subscription token.
Gets the first error (if any) accumulated during HTTP request processing.
The first <xref href="System.Exception"></xref> for the current HTTP request/response process; otherwise, `null` if no errors were accumulated during the HTTP request processing.
The default is `null`.
Returns requested configuration information for the current application.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.GetAppConfig%2A> method has been deprecated.

Use the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.WebConfigurationManager.GetWebApplicationSection%2A> method of the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.WebConfigurationManager> class to get configuration information for the current application.
The application configuration tag for which information is requested.
An object containing configuration information.
(Cast the returned configuration section to the appropriate configuration type before use.)
Returns requested configuration information for the current HTTP request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.GetConfig%2A> method has been deprecated.
Use the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.GetSection%2A> method to get configuration information for the current HTTP request.
The configuration tag for which information is requested.
The specified <xref href="System.Configuration.ConfigurationSection"></xref>, `null` if the section does not exist, or an internal object if the section is not accessible at run time.
(Cast the returned object to the appropriate configuration type before use.)

Gets an application-level resource object based on the specified <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ClassKey"></xref> and <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> properties.

The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.GetGlobalResourceObject%2A> method returns a global resource by using the culture that is specified in the <xref:System.Globalization.CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture%2A> property.

In some editing environments, such as [!INCLUDE[vwprvw](~/includes/vwprvw-md.md)], the editor might throw a design-time <xref:System.Resources.MissingManifestResourceException> exception if you use a period (.) in the global resource-key name.
However, this does not affect your ability to edit or save the file, and you can ignore the error.
A string that represents the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ClassKey"></xref> property of the requested resource object.
A string that represents the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> property of the requested resource object.

An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that represents the requested application-level resource object; otherwise, null if a resource object is not found or if a resource object is found but it does not have the requested property.
A resource object with the specified classKey parameter was not found.
\- or -
The main assembly does not contain the resources for the neutral culture, and these resources are required because the appropriate satellite assembly is missing.

Gets an application-level resource object based on the specified <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ClassKey"></xref> and <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> properties, and on the <xref href="System.Globalization.CultureInfo"></xref> object.
The <xref:System.Globalization.CultureInfo> object represents the culture for which the resource was localized.
If the resource is not localized for this culture, the lookup will follow a fallback process to locate an appropriate resource.
For more information, see [Packaging and Deploying Resources](~/docs/framework/resources/packaging-and-deploying-resources-in-desktop-apps.md).

In some editing environments, such as Visual Web Developer, the editor might throw a design-time <xref:System.Resources.MissingManifestResourceException> exception if you use a period (.) in the global resource-key name.
However, this does not affect your ability to edit or save the file, and you can ignore the error.
A string that represents the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ClassKey"></xref> property of the requested resource object.
A string that represents a <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> property of the requested resource object.
A string that represents the <xref href="System.Globalization.CultureInfo"></xref> object of the requested resource.

An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that represents the requested application-level resource object, which is localized for the specified culture; otherwise, `null` if a resource object is not found or if a resource object is found but it does not have the requested property.
A resource object for which the specified classKey parameter was not found.
\- or -
The main assembly does not contain the resources for the neutral culture, and these resources are required because the appropriate satellite assembly is missing.

Gets a page-level resource object based on the specified <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ExpressionBuilderContext.VirtualPath"></xref> and <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> properties.

The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.GetLocalResourceObject%2A> method returns a local resource by using the culture that is specified in the <xref:System.Globalization.CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture%2A> property.
The <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ExpressionBuilderContext.VirtualPath"></xref> property for the local resource object.
A string that represents a <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> property of the requested resource object
An that represents the requested page-level resource object; otherwise, `null` if a matching resource object is found but not a resourceKey parameter.
A resource object was not found for the specified virtualPath parameter.
The specified virtualPath parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
The resource class for the page was not found.

Gets a page-level resource object based on the specified <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ExpressionBuilderContext.VirtualPath"></xref> and <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> properties, and on the <xref href="System.Globalization.CultureInfo"></xref> object.
If the resource is not localized for this culture, the lookup will follow a fallback process to locate an appropriate resource.
For more information, see [Packaging and Deploying Resources](~/docs/framework/resources/packaging-and-deploying-resources-in-desktop-apps.md).
The <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ExpressionBuilderContext.VirtualPath"></xref> property for the local resource object.
A string that represents a <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ResourceExpressionFields.ResourceKey"></xref> property of the requested resource object.
A string that represents the <xref href="System.Globalization.CultureInfo"></xref> object of the requested resource object.
An that represents the requested local resource object, which is localized for the specified culture; otherwise `null` if a matching resource object is found but not a resourceKey parameter.
A resource object was not found for the specified virtualPath Parameter.
The specified virtualPath parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
The resource class for the page was not found.
Gets a specified configuration section for the current application's default configuration.
The configuration section path (in XPath format) and the configuration element name.
The specified <xref href="System.Configuration.ConfigurationSection"></xref>, `null` if the section does not exist, or an internal object if the section is not accessible at run time.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> object responsible for processing the HTTP request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Handler%2A> property contains a reference to the handler that processes the HTTP request.
The handler can be specified by using the element, or by using a custom handler defined in user code.
For more information about handlers, see [HTTP Handlers and HTTP Modules Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/f540bdeb-d22e-4e1d-ba8a-fe6c9926283b).

The reference to the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Handler%2A> property will remain the same even after the current page has been changed by a server-side method, such as the <xref:System.Web.HttpServerUtility.Execute%2A> method or the <xref:System.Web.HttpServerUtility.Transfer%2A> method.
An <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> responsible for processing the HTTP request.
Gets a value indicating whether custom errors are enabled for the current HTTP request.
`true` if custom errors are enabled; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value indicating whether the current HTTP request is in debug mode.
`true` if the request is in debug mode; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that is the current processing point in the ASP.NET pipeline just after an <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication"></xref> event has finished processing.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.IsPostNotification%2A> property is only supported with the integrated mode in [!INCLUDE[iisver](~/includes/iisver-md.md)] and at least the .NET Framework 3.0.
When available, the property returns a Boolean value that indicates whether an event in the <xref:System.Web.HttpApplication> object has finished processing.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.IsPostNotification%2A> property is not intended to be set.
Instead, it is provided by [!INCLUDE[iisver](~/includes/iisver-md.md)] to the ASP.NET runtime for each notification.
Setting the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.IsPostNotification%2A> property will result in a compilation error.

In scenarios where multiple events of the <xref:System.Web.HttpApplication> object are handled by one event handler, you can use the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.IsPostNotification%2A> property in combination with the <xref:System.Web.RequestNotification> enumeration to precisely determine where in the application lifecycle the current request is.
<xref:System.Web.HttpContext.IsPostNotification%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/docs/framework/migration-guide/versions-and-dependencies.md).
`true` if custom errors are enabled; otherwise, `false`.
The operation requires the integrated pipeline mode in [!INCLUDE[iisver](~/includes/iisver-md.md)] and at least the .NET Framework 3.0.
Gets a value that indicates whether the request is an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request.
This method returns `true` if the request contains the initial <xref:System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket> handshake and the `WebSocket` module of IIS is active.
`true` if the request is an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the connection is upgrading from an HTTP connection to an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> connection.
`true` if the connection is upgrading; otherwise, `false`.

Gets a key/value collection that can be used to organize and share data between an <xref href="System.Web.IHttpModule"></xref> interface and an <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> interface during an HTTP request.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IDictionary"></xref> key/value collection that provides access to an individual value in the collection by a specified key.
Gets a reference to the page-instrumentation service instance for this request.
The page-instrumentation service instance for this request.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> object for the parent handler.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.PreviousHandler%2A> property corresponds to the last handler before the current request was executed.
An <xref href="System.Web.IHttpHandler"></xref> instance, or `null` if no previous handler was found.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.Profile.ProfileBase"></xref> object for the current user profile.
A <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Profile%2A> property is used for persistent storage of structured data using a type-safe API.
When a <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Profile%2A> property is accessed but no value is present, an empty instance is returned; `null` is not returned.
A <xref href="System.Web.Profile.ProfileBase"></xref> if the application configuration file contains a definition for the profile's properties; otherwise, `null`.
Enables you to specify a handler for the request.
If you set `handler` to `null`, the default handler is used to process the request.
You can set `handler` to either an asynchronous handler or to an synchronous handler.
The handler must implement the <xref:System.Web.IHttpHandler> interface.
The object that should process the request.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext.RemapHandler(System.Web.IHttpHandler)"></xref> method was called after the <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication.MapRequestHandler"></xref> event occurred.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Request%2A> property provides programmatic access to the properties and methods of the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest> class.

Because ASP.NET pages contain a default reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace (which contains the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> class), you can reference the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest> on an .aspx page without using the fully qualified class reference to <xref:System.Web.HttpContext>.
For example, you can use `Request.Browser` to get the capabilities of the client browser.

However, if you want to use the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest> from an ASP.NET code-behind module, you must include a reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace in the module and a fully qualified reference to both the currently active request/response context and the class in <xref:System.Web> that you want to use.
For example, in a code-behind page you must specify the fully qualified name `HttpContext.Current.Request.Browser`.
ASP.NET will throw an exception if you try to use this property when the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest> object is not available.
For example, this would be true in the Application_Start method of the Global.asax file, or in a method that is called from the Application_Start method.
At that time no HTTP request has been created yet.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest"></xref> for the current HTTP request.
The Web application is running under IIS 7 in Integrated mode.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.HttpResponse"></xref> object for the current HTTP response.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Response%2A> property provides programmatic access to the properties and methods of the <xref:System.Web.HttpResponse> class.

Because ASP.NET pages contain a default reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace (which contains the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> class), you can reference the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> on an .aspx page without using the fully qualified class reference to <xref:System.Web.HttpContext>.
For example, you can use `Response.Write("some output")` to write output to an HTTP output stream.

However, if you want to use the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpResponse> from an ASP.NET code-behind module, you must include a reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace in the module and a fully qualified reference to the currently active request/response context and the class in <xref:System.Web> that you want to use.
For example, in a code-behind page you must specify the fully qualified name `HttpContext.Current.Response.Write("some output")`.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpResponse"></xref> for the current HTTP response.
The Web application is running under IIS 7 in Integrated mode.
Rewrites the URL using the given virtual path, path information, query string information, and a Boolean value that specifies whether the client file path is set to the rewrite path.
The `filePath` parameter does not include the content of the `pathInfo` parameter.
For the URL http://www.microsoft.com/virdir/page.html/tail, the `filePath` parameter is http://www.microsoft.com/virdir/page.html, and the `pathInfo` parameter is tail.
To ensure that the virtual path that is used to construct paths to resources is not modified, set the `setClientFilePath` parameter to `false`.

A common scenario in which you might want to set `setClientFilePath` to `false` is when you need to rewrite the URL, and you are using themes and redirecting the URL to a resource located in a different folder than the requested resource.

URL rewriting is useful when you want to restructure the pages in your Web application, and you want to make sure that people who have bookmarked old URLs can still use them after you have moved pages.
URL rewriting enables you to transparently forward requests to the new page location.
If you want to enable a site to use URLs that are more user-friendly and are optimized for search engines, a more robust alternative is to use ASP.NET routing.
For more information, see [ASP.NET Routing](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/892441af-8f1d-483e-ab5f-b82c23576f5a).
The virtual path to the resource that services the request.
Additional path information to use for the URL redirect.
For more information, see <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest.PathInfo"></xref>.
The request query string to use for the URL redirect.
`true` to set the file path used for client resources to the value of the filePath parameter; otherwise `false`.
The path parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
The filePath parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
Rewrites the URL by using the given path, path information, and query string information.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.RewritePath%2A> method redirects a request for a resource to another resource without changing the URL.
The `filePath` parameter does not include the `pathInfo` parameter content.
For the URL http://www.microsoft.com/virdir/page.html/tail, the `filePath` parameter is http://www.microsoft.com/virdir/page.html, and the `pathInfo` parameter is tail.

URL rewriting is useful when you want to restructure the pages in your Web application, and you want to make sure that people who have bookmarked old URLs can still use them after you have moved pages.
URL rewriting enables you to transparently forward requests to the new page location.
If you want to enable a site to use URLs that are more user-friendly and are optimized for search engines, a more robust alternative is to use ASP.NET routing.
For more information, see [ASP.NET Routing](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/892441af-8f1d-483e-ab5f-b82c23576f5a).
The internal rewrite path.
Additional path information for a resource.
For more information, see <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest.PathInfo"></xref>.
The request query string.
The path parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
The filePath parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
Rewrites the URL using the given path and a Boolean value that specifies whether the virtual path for server resources is modified.

The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.RewritePath%28System.String%2CSystem.Boolean%29?displayProperty=fullName> method is called by the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.RewritePath%28System.String%29?displayProperty=fullName> method with the `rebaseClientPath` parameter set to `true`.
To ensure that the virtual path that is used to construct paths to resources is not modified, set the `rebaseClientPath` parameter to `false`.

A common scenario in which you might want to set `rebaseClientPath` to `false` is when you need to rewrite the URL, and you are using themes and redirecting the URL to a resource located in a different folder than the requested resource.

URL rewriting is useful when you want to restructure the pages in your Web application, and you want to make sure that people who have bookmarked old URLs can still use them after you have moved pages.
URL rewriting enables you to transparently forward requests to the new page location.
If you want to enable a site to use URLs that are more user-friendly and are optimized for search engines, a more robust alternative is to use ASP.NET routing.
For more information, see [ASP.NET Routing](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/892441af-8f1d-483e-ab5f-b82c23576f5a).
The internal rewrite path.
`true` to reset the virtual path; `false` to keep the virtual path unchanged.
The path parameter is `null`.
The path parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
Rewrites the URL using the given path.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.RewritePath%28System.String%29> method redirects a request for a resource to a different path than the one that is indicated by the requested URL.

If you have to reset the virtual path so that requests from the client for server resources resolve correctly, use the overload of this method that takes the `rebaseClientPath` parameter and set the parameter to `false`.

URL rewriting is useful when you want to restructure the pages in your Web application, and you want to make sure that people who have bookmarked old URLs can still use them after you have moved pages.
URL rewriting enables you to transparently forward requests to the new page location.
If you want to enable a site to use URLs that are more user-friendly and are optimized for search engines, a more robust alternative is to use ASP.NET routing.
For more information, see [ASP.NET Routing](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/892441af-8f1d-483e-ab5f-b82c23576f5a).
The internal rewrite path.
The path parameter is `null`.
The path parameter is not in the current application's root directory.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.HttpServerUtility"></xref> object that provides methods used in processing Web requests.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Server%2A> property provides programmatic access to the properties and methods of the <xref:System.Web.HttpServerUtility> class.

Because ASP.NET pages contain a default reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace (which contains the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> class), you can reference the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> on an .aspx page without using the fully qualified class reference to <xref:System.Web.HttpContext>.
For example, you can use `Server.CreateObject("MyCOMComponent")` to create an instance of a COM object on the server.

However, if you want to use the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpServerUtility> from an ASP.NET code-behind module, you must include a reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace in the module and a fully qualified reference to both the currently active request/response context and the class in <xref:System.Web> that you want to use.
For example, in a code-behind page you must specify the fully qualified name `HttpContext.Current.Server.CreateObject("MyCOMComponent")`.
The <xref href="System.Web.HttpServerUtility"></xref> for the current HTTP request.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.SessionState.HttpSessionState"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Session%2A> property provides programmatic access to the properties and methods of the <xref:System.Web.SessionState.HttpSessionState> class.
In order to use session state you have to enable it.
For information about how to enable session state, see **Configuring Session State** in [ASP.NET Session State Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/6d60d381-6521-4e1d-9089-da6464f2a9bc).
For information about how to save values in session state, see [How to: Save Values in Session State](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/a6cb2e3a-df49-4b12-9d9a-eed45541c165).
For information about how to read values from session state, see [How to: Read Values from Session State](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/2ef449bc-5c17-4785-b7cf-378c601af8f5).
The <xref href="System.Web.SessionState.HttpSessionState"></xref> object for the current HTTP request.
Sets the type of session state behavior that is required in order to support an HTTP request.

In the ASP.NET default implementation, an HTTP request handler indicates whether it requires session state by implementing the <xref:System.Web.SessionState.IRequiresSessionState> interface or the <xref:System.Web.SessionState.IReadOnlySessionState> interface.

The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.SetSessionStateBehavior%2A> method and the <xref:System.Web.SessionState.SessionStateBehavior> enumeration let you provide more detail about what type of session state support is required in order to handle a request.
For more information, see the <xref:System.Web.SessionState.SessionStateBehavior> enumeration.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.SetSessionStateBehavior%2A> method must be called before the <xref:System.Web.HttpApplication.AcquireRequestState> pipeline event.
Calls that occur during or after this event will cause an <xref:System.InvalidOperationException> exception.
One of the enumeration values that specifies what type of session state behavior is required.
The method was called after the <xref href="System.Web.HttpApplication.AcquireRequestState"></xref> event was raised.
Gets or sets a value that specifies whether the <xref href="System.Web.Security.UrlAuthorizationModule"></xref> object should skip the authorization check for the current request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.SkipAuthorization%2A> property is intended for advanced use by authentication modules that need to redirect to a page that allows anonymous connections.
The Forms authentication module and Passport authentication module both set <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.SkipAuthorization%2A> when redirecting to a configured logon page.
Setting <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.SkipAuthorization%2A> requires the `ControlPrincipal` flag to be set.
For information about the `ControlPrincipal` flag, see <xref:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag>.
`true` if <xref href="System.Web.Security.UrlAuthorizationModule"></xref> should skip the authorization check; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Gets or sets a value that specifies whether the ASP.NET runtime should call <xref href="System.Threading.Thread.Abort"></xref> on the thread that is servicing this request when the request times out.

In handlers and modules that are using the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.TimedOutToken%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property to implement cooperative cancellation, you might wish to disable the <xref:System.Threading.Thread.Abort%2A?displayProperty=fullName> behavior that ASP.NET performs by default when a request times out.
Setting this property to `false` can help you make sure that cancellation and cleanup routines will run without being interrupted by ASP.NET.
If you set this property to `false`, ASP.NET will not automatically display a "Request timed out" error page when a timeout occurs.
The application is responsible for setting the response content appropriately.
`true` if <xref href="System.Threading.Thread.Abort"></xref> will be called when the thread times out; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Gets the initial timestamp of the current HTTP request.
The timestamp returned from the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Timestamp%2A> property is the local time of the server and is set during the instantiation of the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> object.
The local time is equal to the UTC time plus the UTC offset.
The timestamp of the current HTTP request.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.TraceContext"></xref> object for the current HTTP response.
The <xref href="System.Web.TraceContext"></xref> for the current HTTP response.
Gets or sets security information for the current HTTP request.
The <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.User%2A> property provides programmatic access to the properties and methods of the <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal> interface.

Because ASP.NET pages contain a default reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace (which contains the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> class), you can reference the members of <xref:System.Web.HttpContext> on an .aspx page without using the fully qualified class reference to <xref:System.Web.HttpContext>.
For example, you can use `User.Identity.Name` to get the name of the user on whose behalf the current process is running.

However, if you want to use the members of <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal> from an ASP.NET code-behind module, you must include a reference to the <xref:System.Web> namespace in the module and a fully qualified reference to both the currently active request/response context and the class in <xref:System.Web> that you want to use.
For example, in a code-behind page you must specify the fully qualified name `HttpContext.Current.User.Identity.Name`.
Security information for the current HTTP request.
Gets the negotiated protocol that was sent from the server to the client for an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> connection.
The negotiated protocol.
Gets the ordered list of protocols requested by the client.
The requested protocols, or `null` if this is not an <xref href="System.Web.WebSockets.AspNetWebSocket"></xref> request or if no list is present.
Returns an object for the current service type.
This method is useful to gain access to the underlying <xref:System.Web.HttpWorkerRequest> object.
A type of <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref> service to set the service provider to.
A <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref>; otherwise, `null` if no service is found.
